articles.title: Aerial survey of Gisborne regional wetlands under way
articles.author: Gisborne Herald
articles.summary: Aerial survey of the region's wetlands by fixed-wing aircraft has started. It will run until June. Low-flying aircraft will capture images to help map wetlands and support improvements to the Te Karaka and Waipaoa flood control schemes.

articles.title: Shear line to bring heavy rain over Luzon, Eastern Visayas
articles.author: By:
articles.summary: Moderate to intense rains are expected over the eastern sections of Luzon and Visayas due to the shear line. The northeast monsoon or amihan and the easterlies continue to affect the country, bringing cooler temperatures. A gale warning has also been hoisted over the following major seaboards in the country: Northern, western, and eastern seaboard of Northern Luzon, Central and Southern Luzon.

articles.title: ‘Enough is enough': Australians ‘fed up' with lack of leadership on antisemitic attacks
articles.summary: There are reports of another antisemitic attack in Sydney involving offensive graffiti being sprayed on a house in the beachside suburb of Maroubra. Australia Israel and Jewish Affairs Council's Dr Colin Rubenstein says the spate of incidents across Australia have become 'tolerated' and 'normalised'.

articles.title: Tvm fares better than Kochi in face of rising sea levels
articles.author: Sudha.Nambudiri
articles.summary: Thiruvananthapuram's coastline has shown greater resilience to rising sea levels than Kochi's. Kochi is expected to sink at a faster rate of 10-20mm per year than Thiruvanthapurams. Ernakulam has witnessed a five-fold increase in sea surge events despite having Kerala's shortest coastline. Coastal areas such as Chellanam and Edavanakkad have been identified as hotspots.

articles.title: Nat Fortune: Bad climate arguments
articles.summary: Letters to the editor regularly argue that there is no need to worry about climate change. Scientists have long known that adding carbon dioxide to the atmosphere will lead to a warming planet, why it will do so, and have seen that it is doing so. In the geological past, periods of rapid warming were instigated by the rapid release of carbon dioxide or greatly accelerated by its release.

articles.title: Okumu Modachi, Alex Kiarie And AFP
articles.author: Standard Group Plc
articles.summary: The urgency of the climate crisis is being felt more acutely in climate-vulnerable countries like Kenya. Global leaders are preparing for the COP29 summit, which will take place in COP29 in Nairobi, Kenya on November 29th and 30th.

articles.title: Frequency of Western Disturbances may drop 11-17% over S Asia by 2100: Study
articles.author: Gaurav.Talwar
articles.summary: Western Disturbances, responsible for winter precipitation over western Himalayas, are undergoing significant changes due to climate change. Global warming may weaken the subtropical jet stream and shift WDs towards the poles. This shift could lead to a decline in WD activity over South Asia. WDs play a critical role in maintaining health of Himalayan glaciers.

articles.title: Climate change increased the odds of Los Angeles' devastating fires, researchers say
articles.author: Anna Washenko
articles.summary: Earth is currently 1.3°C hotter than before the industrial era. Extreme Fire Weather Index conditions are 35% more likely to occur in the LA area at this temperature. If the planet increases 2.6°C from its pre-industrial temperature, extreme conditions become another 35%. The Earth is projected to reach this temperature by the year 2100.

articles.title: Cape Fear Habitat for Humanity announces new president and CEO
articles.author: WECT Staff
articles.summary: Marlowe Foster will assume the position of president and CEO of Cape Fear Habitat for Humanity on February 18th. He previously served as the CEO of Habitat of North Carolina. Foster has represented BASF, Pfizer, and Lowe's Companies, Inc. in government and community affairs, communications, and corporate foundation management. He also served as senior vice president for development and business strategy at the Food Bank of Central and Eastern NC.

articles.title: Psychology Behind Denial Of Climate Change
articles.summary: Climate change has become an overwhelming concern due to the atrocities it has brought forth worldwide. It is the result of mankind's years of misuse of planet Earth's natural resources. This has been proven repeatedly by each of the climate scientists who have conducted the research.

articles.title: Climate finance and Global South
articles.summary: The withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement is a setback to global climate action. Pakistan is a climate-vulnerable country. Pakistan needs to focus on local climate finance, engage in public-private partnerships and explore mechanisms like green entrepreneurship and climate risk insurance. Regional cooperation can provide shared financing and technology transfer opportunities.

articles.title: Greek farmers at an impasse
articles.author: Newsroom
articles.summary: Greek farmers are demanding changes to the Hellenic Agricultural Insurance Organization regulations to expand compensation coverage for climate-induced damage. The agriculture sector is suffering, with climate change increasing damage – impacting nearly 60% of crops in recent years. Issues include heat-damaged melons, failing olive harvests, and uninsurable mildew outbreaks.

articles.title: Speed cameras aren't saving lives
articles.author: Marton Pettendy
articles.summary: Australia has recorded its highest annual road toll since 2012. It's the fourth consecutive year in which road fatalities have increased. It hasn't happened since 1966, before seatbelts became mandatory in all new cars. It is the first time since 1966 that the number of road fatalities has increased since then.

articles.title: Nigeria, Australia Strengthen Ties with Bilateral Talks on Trade, Agriculture, and Mining
articles.author: Michael Olugbode
articles.summary: Australia has moved to strengthen ties with Nigeria with the visit of high-level delegation from the country led by the First Assistant Secretary, Middle East and Africa Division, Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Marc Innes-Brown. The visit is aimed at strengthening economic ties and exploring new areas of cooperation, particularly in trade, mining, agriculture, and food security.

articles.title: Climate change made deadly LA wildfires 'more likely', conclude leading scientists
articles.author: NME
articles.summary: Wildfires in Los Angeles are 35% more likely due to human-caused climate change, according to a group of leading climate scientists. One charity supports more than 2,500 affected music industry workers, which has left one charity supporting more than 1,500 people.

articles.title: Climate change is speeding up, study of ocean warming reveals
articles.author: Patrick Pester
articles.summary: Earth's oceans are getting warmer at an accelerating rate, according to a new study published in the journal Environmental Research Letters. Ocean warming has more than quadrupled over the past 40 years and is likely to accelerate even faster in the future. Global warming drives rising sea levels, fuels more extreme weather and dries out land, compromising our ability to grow food.

articles.title: Ocean warming 4 times faster than in 1980s — and likely to accelerate in coming decades
articles.summary: Earth's oceans are getting warmer at an accelerating rate, according to a new study published in the journal Environmental Research Letters. Ocean warming has more than quadrupled over the past 40 years and is likely to accelerate even faster in the future. Global warming drives rising sea levels, fuels more extreme weather and dries out land, compromising our ability to grow food.

articles.title: Experts urge 'stronger' gov't support for women in agriculture
articles.summary: Jordan's agricultural sector is facing unprecedented challenges due to climate change. 88% of women working in agriculture have reported a decline in their output due to these environmental changes. 99.1% of female agricultural workers in Jordan are involved in crop cultivation. The Ministry of Agriculture is implementing climate-smart agricultural projects aimed at boosting production.

articles.title: U.S. to Withdraw From Paris Agreement Next January
articles.summary: The United States will withdraw from the Paris Agreement on January 27th of the coming year. The U.S. is the second-largest emitter of greenhouse gases in the world. The decision may undermine US credibility on the international stage and hinder global environmental cooperation.

articles.title: 2025 Christmas Bird Count circle diverse
articles.author: Andy Tait
articles.summary: The Millet-Wetaskiwin Christmas Bird Count was performed by 11 surveyors and resulted in 478 individual birds tallied, comprised of 25 species, down from past years. The most common species this year are the Downy and Pileated woodpecker, Northern flicker and Blue jay, along with the Black-capped chickadee, Red-breasted nuthatch and White-winged crossbill.

articles.title: Climate change could have been factor in California wildfires, study finds
articles.summary: Climate change could have been a factor in the recent California wildfires, study finds. It's possible that climate change could be a factor.    for the recent southern California wildfires. It could also be a cause of the recent drought. It is possible that it could be the cause of droughts.

articles.title: Cape Fear Habitat hires Marlowe Foster as president and CEO
articles.author: Wway News
articles.summary: Marlowe Foster has been hired as President and CEO of Cape Fear Habitat for Humanity. He will assume his new position on February 18th. Foster is a seasoned executive with over 25 years of senior-level experience. He represented BASF, Pfizer, and Lowe's Companies, Inc. in government and community affairs, communications, and corporate foundation management. He also served as Senior Vice President for Development and Business Strategy at the Food Bank of Central and Eastern NC.

articles.title: Climate crisis amplified
articles.author: Fayyaz Salih Hussain
articles.summary: Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris Agreement on climate change has far-reaching consequences for the world, particularly for developing nations. The UN Secretary-General António Guterres has warned that such a withdrawal could lead to a 'crippled' Paris Agreement. Without US participation, other nations may feel less compelled to meet their own commitments, leading to an increase in global emissions. In Africa alone, crop yields could decrease by as much as 50 percent by 2020 due to climate impacts.

articles.title: Green choices, green spaces
articles.author: Anne Elspeth Rector
articles.summary: At a time when green efforts matter enormously, have you noticed how much browner our world is? January saw Los Angeles scorched to the ground, try imagining Canada's summer. Climate change and its catastrophic consequences are being buried amid shifting political priorities, writes John Sutter.

articles.title: Green choices, green spaces
articles.author: Anne Elspeth Rector
articles.summary: Belleville is holding a public information session on the Former Queen Mary School Affordable Housing Project on Tuesday, February 4 at Prince Charles Public School, 75 Ritchie Avenue from 4:30 to 6:30 p.m. West Hill youth have the only publicly designated 'parklands' Belleville Council preferred the proposal that preserves two southern acres of parklands.

articles.title: Los Angeles wildfires linked to climate change, report states
articles.summary: At least 29 people died in the Los Angeles wildfires. The hot, dry and windy conditions that fueled the fires were about 35 percent more likely due to warming linked to the burning of oil, gas and coal. The researchers emphasize that climate change increases the risk of such catastrophic fires in the LA area.

articles.title: Australian Heatwave Stories Cop Severe Criticism
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: Geoff Sherrington presents a heatwave analysis of 10 weather stations in Australia. The study has generated 160 graphs that are linked by weather station/city. Australia's BOM issue special statements about heatwaves. In November 2023, south-west Western Australia, including Perth and Cape Leeuwin, had a record warm global sea surface temperatures.

articles.title: Why has the Doomsday Clock moved a second closer to midnight? Why scientists fear nuclear war in Ukraine, AI-designed terrorist biological weapons and climate change are leading us to Armageddon
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: The Doomsday Clock has been moved to a record-breaking 89 seconds to midnight. This represents the closest humanity has ever been to global catastrophe in its 78-year history. The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists considers moving the Doomsday Clock closer to midnight to symbolize the increasing threat to global security posed by nuclear proliferation and climate change.

articles.title: New Study Reveals Climate Change Alters Species Distribution Like a Deck of
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: A new study from the University of California, Santa Cruz highlights the destabilizing effects of temperature changes on animal populations. The research has significant implications for biodiversity and ecosystem stability. The lead author, Malin Pinsky, likens the ecological impacts of rapid temperature changes to shuffling a deck of cards. Pinsky emphasizes the importance of reducing fishing pressures and protecting marine environments.

articles.title: Study Says Changing Climate Made Southern California Wildfires More Likely, More Intense
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Global warming increased the likelihood and intensity of the recent Southern California wildfires by 35% and its intensity by 6%. Once-in-a-decade Santa Ana winds, a dry autumn that followed two wet years, hot weather, dry air and vulnerable houses in fire-prone areas were factors in the fast-moving fires that destroyed thousands of homes and killed at least 29 people.

articles.title: Antarctica's Biodiversity: New Mapping Breakthrough Revealed
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: Australian researchers have created a detailed map of Antarctica's ice-free land that they say will help protect the continent's biodiversity. The team, led by the University of New South Wales (UNSW) Sydney, unveiled a new high-resolution map and a hierarchical classification system of the ecosystems in Antarctica on Wednesday.

articles.title: Changing weather patterns
articles.author: Gk Editorial Desk
articles.summary: There has been a change in the day temperatures and the sunshine during the day. Experts warn about the grave environmental impact of climate change. People need to preserve their own space and make sure that even the bigger adverse changes impact them less and less. If right regulations are put in place and a responsible approach adopted at the societal level, we can expect a welcome change.

articles.title: Climate change reshuffles species like a deck of cards, new study says
articles.author: Jasmin Galvan
articles.summary: Temperatures change more rapidly due to climate change, according to a new study by Malin Pinsky, an ecology and evolutionary biologist at UC Santa Cruz. The study's findings are unique because the impacts of temperature change have often not been clear on land or in freshwater ecosystems. It is these animals that are most at risk due to faster temperature changes.

articles.title: Climate change made conditions that fed California wildfires more likely, intense: Study
articles.author: NBC Bay Area
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change increased the likelihood and intensity of the recent Southern California wildfires, according to a scientific study. The number (35%) doesn't sound like much, but it's a significant factor in the study's findings.

articles.title: Charlestown Land Trust Winter Speaker Series: Salt Marsh Restoration in Charlestown
articles.summary: Wenley Ferguson, director of habitat restoration at Save The Bay, will present on salt marsh restoration in Charlestown and throughout the salt ponds and Narragansett Bay. Salt marshes across Rhode Island face significant challenges, from historical alterations like drainage ditches to the accelerating impacts of sea level rise.

articles.title: Maputo's Flood Struggles: Climate Crisis and Financial Challenges
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Flooding is a problem in Mozambique, worsened by climate change and financial constraints. Cyclones have claimed over 130 lives recently. Government responses are hampered by insufficient funds and underdeveloped infrastructure. Critics argue that palliative solutions do not address fundamental problems.

articles.title: Working together needed on common problem for U.S. and Canada: Climate Change
articles.author: Paula Peterson
articles.summary: Claire Martin is an award-winning television host and weather presenter. She gave a talk on climate change at Lake Tahoe Community College's Duke Theatre. Canada is experiencing a widespread drought, melting permafrost that is releasing methane, and higher temperatures than ever before experienced. In Canada, January is normally their snowiest month. In 2021, the Western North American heat wave killed over 1,400 people in Canada.

articles.title: The Ocean Surface Is Heating Up At An Alarming Rate—And It's Only Getting Worse
articles.author: Melissa Ait Lounis
articles.summary: The world's oceans are warming 400% faster than in the 1980s. Sea surface temperatures are rising at a rate of 0.27 °C per decade. The next 20 years could bring more warming than the last 40 years combined. Reducing fossil fuel consumption is the single most effective way to curb ocean warming.

articles.title: Climate schadenfreude
articles.author: Judith Sloan
articles.summary: Every time there is a natural disaster, the green and climate believers use it to justify even tougher action on climate change. The compassion is qualified by the warning that unless more is done to limit the rise in global temperatures, we should expect more catastrophic events.

articles.title: Oceans Warming Four Times Faster Than in Last Four Decades, Study Finds
articles.author: Hans India Digital
articles.summary: The rate at which oceans are warming has increased dramatically over the past few decades. From 2019 to 2023, ocean temperatures have been increasing by 0.27°C per decade, compared to just 0.06°C in the late 1980s. The energy imbalance in Earth's energy, driven largely by rising greenhouse gas emissions, has doubled since 2010, leading to faster warming of the oceans. Global ocean temperatures hit record highs in 2023 and continued into early 2024, with El Nino contributing to the spike.

articles.title: Winter weather travel advisory ends for Pembroke, Arnprior, Carleton Place, Smiths Falls, Perth, Renfrew, Kemptville
articles.author: Metroland Staff
articles.summary: Winter weather travel advisory for Pembroke, Arnprior, Carleton Place, Smiths Falls, Perth, Renfrew, Kemptville has ended. Snowfall amounts of four to eight centimetres are expected Tuesday night and into Wednesday morning.

articles.title: Canada Invests in Climate Change Adaptation to Keep Communities Safe in Northern Ontario and Across Canada
articles.summary: $2.7 million in funding announced for five projects based in northern Ontario under the Climate Change Adaptation Program (CCAP). The projects aim to support professionals, decision makers and First Nation communities to advance the implementation of climate change adaptation plans and actions. One of the projects will identify lessons learned from previously implemented adaptation actions.

articles.title: 'Less snow': warm January weather breaks records in Moscow
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Two of the past days in Moscow broke all-time daily temperature highs. January 2025 is on track to be one of the warmest in Moscow on record. Temperatures are much higher than the historical average below freezing. There is less snow for children to play with and there is mud everywhere in Moscow.

articles.title: Oceans warming four times faster than in 1980s, study finds
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: Oceans are warming at 0.27 degrees Celsius per decade during 2019-23, compared to 0.06 degrees Celsius every decade in the late 1980s. Global ocean temperatures hit record highs for 450 days straight in 2023 and early 2024. The authors warn that the ocean temperature increase seen over the past 40 years could be exceeded in the next 20 years.

articles.title: Kazakhstan sets up working group of experts to tackle Caspian Sea shallowing
articles.author: Adlet Seilkhanov
articles.summary: The state of the Caspian Sea is being closely observed by all the littoral states, as its water level continues declining. The water level and state are always on the table at summits and meetings of the Framework Convention for the Protection of the Marine Environment (Tehran Convention) signed by Republic of Azerbaijan, Islamic Republic of Iran, Republic of Kazakhstan, Russian Federation, and Turkmenistan. Baku hosted the side event discussing the water decline in light of climate change at COP29 under Azerbaijan's chairmanship on November 18 last year. Kazakhstan is to create a five-sided working group of experts to study changes in the water level of the Sea.

articles.title: Soaring Temperatures Threaten 50% Global GDP Contraction, Climate Facts Reveal
articles.author: Agnes Ekebuike
articles.summary: A new report warns of the economic devastation that could result from unchecked global warming. Global GDP could contract by 50% within this century if current emission trends continue. The report stresses that the most vulnerable populations in developing countries will bear the brunt of the consequences. Naija247news will continue to track this critical issue and report on developments.

articles.title: 2025 Drought In The Caribbean A Potential Threat.
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Drought in parts of the Caribbean during the first half of 2025 is a cause for concern for the Caribbean Drought and Precipitation Monitoring Network. Short-term drought could affect small rivers, streams and ponds in the northern Bahamas islands and Cuba by the end of March, and long drought could impact large rivers, reservoirs, and groundwater in Belize from April to June.

articles.title: How a new NASA satellite could help solve the global temperature spike mystery
articles.author: DAN PECK
articles.summary: Last year, 2024 was the warmest year on record for the planet, easily breaking the previous record set just a year earlier. El Niño event is a primary driver of this huge spike in global surface temperatures since mid-2023. NASA's newest Earth-observing satellite, PACE, is expected to provide new data to help scientists understand how changing levels of different atmospheric aerosols impact Earth's energy balance and global temperature trends.

articles.title: Milder winter may shift H5N1 seasonal pattern
articles.author: Dustin Hoffmann
articles.summary: Last year's H5N1 (avian influenza) season was prolonged because of the prolonged fall and unusually mild start of winter. Migratory birds are already beginning their journey north earlier than expected. Iowa Ag Secretary Mike Naig and I talked about the implications of those ducks and geese heading back in the opposite direction from only a month ago.

articles.title: Nigeria, Australia strengthen economic ties in bilateral talks
articles.author: Kazeem Biriowo
articles.summary: Nigeria and Australia have commenced high-level bilateral consultations aimed at strengthening economic ties and exploring new areas of cooperation. The talks aim to map out practical measures to strengthen cooperation in areas like trade, investment, and climate change. Marc Innes-Brown, First Assistant Secretary, Middle East and Africa Division, Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, expressed his appreciation for the warm welcome and the breadth of the Nigerian delegation.

articles.title: The pioneering science linking climate to weather disasters
articles.author: Julien MIVIELLE
articles.summary: In the field of attribution science, experts examine the possible influence of global warming on a specific weather event. World Weather Attribution (WWA) is the most active and influential group of researchers. It found that climate change increased the risk of the Los Angeles wildfires, which killed at least 29 people and destroyed more than 10,000 homes since January 7.

articles.title: The pioneering science linking climate to weather disasters
articles.author: Julien MIVIELLE
articles.summary: Extreme weather is becoming more destructive as the world warms. Thanks to attribution science, experts can examine the possible influence of global warming on a specific weather event, such as the fires in Los Angeles, typhoons in the Philippines, or flooding in Spain.

articles.title: Oceans warming four times faster than in 1980s, study finds
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: Oceans are warming at 0.27 degrees Celsius per decade during 2019-23, compared to 0.06 degrees Celsius every decade in the late 1980s. The way to slow down the warming is to cut global carbon emissions and move towards net-zero. The accelerated warming of oceans is driven by a growing imbalance in Earth's energy.

articles.title: Ireland had warmest and wettest year on record in 2023
articles.author: Sarah Slater
articles.summary: 2023 was the warmest and wettest year on record in Ireland. The average temperature in 2023 was 10.96 degrees, while 1,511 millimetres of rain was recorded. Greenhouse gas emissions in Ireland fell by 6.8 per cent in the same year, down to 55 million tonnes from 59 million tonnes in 2022. China was the world's largest producer of greenhouse gases in 2022 at 13.9 billion tonnes, more than twice the US's figure of 6 billion tonnes. Renewable energy accounted for 41 per cent of electricity generation in Ireland in the year 2023.

articles.title: Study shows weather factors affect Salmonella transmission
articles.summary: Climate change is impacting the spread of Salmonella, according to new research from the University of Surrey. Previous research found that weather change is leading to the spread the dangerous diarrheal illness. Salmonellas are a leading cause of foodborne illnesses in Europe.

articles.title: Pakistan to experience rain and temperature drop this weekend
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: A rainy weather system is expected to enter Pakistan between January 31 and February 1. It will bring cooler temperatures and relief from the ongoing dry spell. Climate change has shortened winter this year, leading to warmer afternoons and colder nights. The lack of rain has contributed to rising temperatures.

articles.title: New Helene recovery pop-up events for farmers, agricultural producers in WNC
articles.author: Helen Chickering
articles.summary: Farmers and agricultural producers in Western North Carolina are getting support from FEMA, the USDA, and the North Carolina Department of Agriculture. The first events were held in Henderson and McDowell counties. Upcoming Agricultural Recovery Fairs are planned in Ashe, Avery, Burke, Mitchell, and Yancey counties.

articles.title: Finally, an answer to why Earth's oceans have been on a record hot streak
articles.author: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
articles.summary: Earth's oceans have been on a record-hot streak since March 2023. Since then, the bathwater-like conditions have killed corals, fueled hurricanes, and collapsed entire fisheries. The rate of ocean warming has more than quadrupled over the past 40 years, driven by Earth's growing energy imbalance. The next 20 years could warm up the oceans more than the last 40 years.

articles.title: Climate ‘threatening tourism jobs'
articles.author: Shawn Cumberbatch
articles.summary: Climate change is a big threat to jobs in Barbados and the Caribbean, especially tourism related employment. The International Labour Organisation (ILO) urges the region to take major action on climate change resilience and adaptation to counter the short and long term climatic impacts on employment and livelihoods in the Caribbean.

articles.title: March In January
articles.author: Editorial Board
articles.summary: Temperatures in Kashmir have been fluctuating wildly since the two weeks of intense cold in December. The weather has been largely sunny and warm yet again in the valley with the day temperature climbing many notches above normal. Unseasonably warm weather has become a recurring phenomenon the world over. Last year in April in South Asia, millions of people faced sweltering temperatures and 110 people died due to heatstroke. According to UNICEF, four times as many South Asian children could be exposed to extreme heatwaves in the 2050s.

articles.title: What Davos delegates missed when they discussed green finance for business
articles.author: Michael Harrison
articles.summary: This year's theme at the forum was safeguarding the planet. Human-caused climate change has cost the planet US$3.6trn (£2.9trn) in damage since 2000, according to the forum's own figures.

articles.title: Closer Than Ever: Doomsday Clock Advanced To' 89 Seconds To Midnight
articles.author: Lorraine Swanson
articles.summary: Atomic Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists moved the minute hand on the Doomsday Clock from 90 seconds to 89 seconds to midnight. The closest the clock came to catastrophe was two minutes to midnight in 1953. The Doomsday Clock has been moved 26 times in its 78-year history.

articles.title: Scientists are blaming the Los Angeles wildfires on climate change
articles.author: SHIVALI BEST
articles.summary: The World Weather Attribution, a network of researchers from the US, UK and Europe, says climate change is to blame for the devastating Los Angeles wildfires that killed at least 28 people and destroyed more than 10,000 homes. Global warming has made the fires 35% more likely due to the Santa Ana winds and drought conditions.

articles.title: Climate crisis threatens Latin America's fight against hunger, UN report says
articles.author: bne Intelli News
articles.summary: Latin America and the Caribbean are second only to Asia in their exposure to extreme weather events due to climate change. The number of people experiencing hunger in the region dropped to 41 million in 2023. UN agencies warn that without accelerated action to build resilience within agrifood systems, the gains could be reversed.

articles.title: Severe heatwave forecast for Mallee
articles.author: Allan Murphy
articles.summary: The Bureau of Meteorology has forecast severe heatwave conditions across much of western Victoria for the three days beginning February 1st. Some extended weather predictors are predicting up to nine consecutive days of 39 degrees or above in some parts of the Mallee, north west and southwestern NSW.

articles.title: Climate change made LA wildfires 'more likely' according to international study
articles.author: RFI
articles.summary: Climate change caused by human activity increases the risk of devastating fires, according to the World Weather Attribution network. The fires in Los Angeles left at least 29 dead and thousands homeless. The study concluded that the fire-prone conditions fueling the blazes were 35 percent more likely due to global warming caused by burning fossil fuels.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Puts Central American Food Supply at Risk
articles.author: Tico Times
articles.summary: Food security in southern Mexico and parts of Central America is at risk due to extreme weather events such as droughts. 14 countries in Latin America and the Caribbean may see restricted access to food due to the climate crisis. Food insecurity increased by an average of 1.5% between 2019 and 2023 in vulnerable countries.

articles.title: Oceans warming rate has become four times faster as compared to last four decades, finds study
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: Oceans are warming at 0.27 degrees Celsius per decade during 2019-23, compared to 0.06 degrees Celsius every decade in the late 1980s. Global ocean temperatures hit record highs for 450 days straight in 2023 and early 2024. Nearly half of the record-breaking heat could be traced back to oceans warming at an accelerating rate.

articles.title: Welcome to the Pyrocene
articles.author: Stephen Pyne
articles.summary: In recent years, fires have blasted through cities in Colorado, the southern Appalachians, the island of Maui, Canada, Australia, Portugal and Greece. Human activity has been reforging the Earth since the end of the last glaciation, about 11,500 years ago. The transition to a fossil-fuel civilization has affected how people live on the land, how they design cities and peri-urban communities and how they shape living landscapes.

articles.title: Oceans Warming Four Times Faster, Warns New Study
articles.author: Press Trust
articles.summary: Oceans are warming at 0.27 degrees Celsius per decade during 2019-23, compared to 0.06 degrees Celsius every decade in the late 1980s. Global ocean temperatures hit record highs for 450 days straight in 2023 and early 2024 due to the El Nino.

articles.title: Global Threats Push Doomsday Clock to Record Low
articles.author: David M. Higgins II
articles.summary: The Doomsday Clock moved to 89 seconds away from midnight Tuesday. The new setting marks the closest the clock has ever been to signaling the potential end of humanity. The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists cited escalating risks from nuclear weapons, climate change, geopolitical tensions, and artificial intelligence in military applications as the reasons for the change.

articles.title: Incredible pictures as rare exotic bird turns up at Isle of Man farm
articles.summary: The species of bright white heron has seen a rapid expansion in recent decades. It has colonised much of Europe, the Americas and as far north as Canada. It is thought that climate change is to blame for the change in the species' habitat.

articles.title: Climate change could spark outbreaks of DIARRHOEA in Britain, scientists warn
articles.author: JONATHAN CHADWICK
articles.summary: Scientists from the University of Surrey found a link between warmer conditions and more salmonella cases in England and Wales. They also found that the days were longer and there was more sunlight. The scientists admit that they cannot be sure of the cause of the rise in salmonellosis cases.

articles.title: Oceans warming four times faster than in 1980s, finds study
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: There is a growing imbalance in the Earth's energy. Energy from the Sun is being absorbed by Earth more than it is escaping back to space. This leads to the accelerated warming of the oceans, which is driven by the imbalance in Earth's solar energy.

articles.title: Legislator seeks preparation of disaster map
articles.author: Jovee Marie N. de la Cruz
articles.summary: Bicol Saro Rep. Brian Raymund Yamsuan has filed a bill that mandates the development and issuance of a national disaster map to help save lives and mitigate losses from natural calamities. The previous year, the country experienced a record-breaking severe typhoon season that led to the loss of thousands of lives and massive damages to homes, infrastructure and the agriculture sector.

articles.title: UK backs third Heathrow runway in growth takeoff bid
articles.author: Ben Perry
articles.summary: Greenpeace warns expanding Heathrow will increase 'noise, air pollution and climate emissions' at the airport. Adrian Dennis is a writer and editor at docafp.com, part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange (BLOX).

articles.title: We are living in a new era
articles.summary: Scientists say 2024 will be the hottest year on record due to human-caused climate change. Wildfires are highly unusual in Southern California in January, which is supposed to be the rainy season. In Europe, extreme heat contributed to at least 47,000 deaths in 2023 and heat-related deaths in the United States have doubled in recent decades.

articles.title: Climate change worsened LA wildfires, researchers say
articles.author: Chelsea Harvey
articles.summary: The recent Los Angeles wildfires were made worse by climate change, scientists say. Hot, dry, windy conditions in Southern California this winter were 35 percent more likely to occur because of human-caused climate change. The world is on track to warm by at least 2.6 degrees by the end of this century.

articles.title: Oceans warming four times faster than in 1980s, study finds
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Oceans are warming at a rate four times faster than four decades ago, reaching 0.27 degrees Celsius per decade.      .   "Ocean warming is happening at a faster rate than 4 decades ago".   i

articles.title: The Doomsday Clock has moved even closer to midnight - but what does it mean?
articles.author: Bethan Finighan
articles.summary: The Doomsday Clock has moved forward one second to 89 seconds to midnight. In its 78-year history, the clock has never been closer to a world-ending catastrophe than now. Scientists cited the Russia-Ukraine war, conflicts in the Middle East, the threat of nuclear war and AI, and climate change as the reason behind the first move forward in two years.

articles.title: Has the World Lost Its Collective Mind?
articles.author: Administrator
articles.summary: Martin Armstrong is the founder and editor-in-chief of The Burning Platform. He is asking for donations to keep the site alive and the forum open for discussion and discussion of the issues discussed there.   He asks you to consider the value you receive from the site and the community of which you are a vital part.

articles.title: Mark W. Schwiebert: Some thoughts on the environment for the new year
articles.author: Mark Schwiebert
articles.summary: In the new year, we consider the many blessings we've been given. One of the greatest blessings we experience daily is the natural world around us. In the Jewish and Christian traditions, God entrusted humans with responsibility for the stewardship and caretaking of nature. Evangelical Christians believe that our careless conduct toward a natural world violated God's purpose.

articles.title: Oceans Heat Up Four Times Faster: Alarming Climate Change Signal
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Oceans are warming four times faster than in the past four decades. The energy imbalance has nearly doubled since 2010. The study underscores the urgent need to curb fossil fuel use to stabilize the climate. Chris Merchant advocates for cutting global carbon emissions and striving for net-zero.

articles.title: Experts warn new factor could devastate home values: 'A potential disaster in slow motion'
articles.author: Timothy McGill
articles.summary: Rising sea levels are projected to put some prime waterfront properties underwater in British Columbia, Canada. Climate Central's Coastal Risk Screening Tool shows which coastlines around the world would be submerged based on various projections of sea level rise. John Clague, an earth sciences professor at Simon Fraser University, called it "a potential disaster in slow motion"

articles.title: York Library hosts 2025 series on climate change: From sea level rise to offshore wind
articles.author: Seacoast Online
articles.summary: The York Public Library is hosting its fourth annual educational series focusing on climate change, titled "Climate Change: Coastal Impacts and Resources". It's in partnership with York Ready for Climate Action and York Land Trust, and it's called "Climate change: Coastalimpacts and resources".

articles.title: UN Secretary General issues urgent worldwide call after alarming milestone: 'We must exit this road to ruin'
articles.author: Timothy McGill
articles.summary: 2014 was the warmest year on the planet for both the United States and globally. The global surface temperature was 2.32 degrees above the 20th-century average. The contiguous U.S. also saw unprecedented warmth in 2024, with average temperatures soaring almost 4 degrees above normal. U.N. Secretary General António Guterres said in 2025, countries must put the world on a safer path by cutting emissions.

articles.title: Dartmoor's disappearing areas could spell climate disaster
articles.author: Lewis Clarke
articles.summary: Dartmoor, one of England's most treasured landscapes, is on the brink of an ecological crisis due to climate change. The Flow Country, Dartmoor and the Peak District are particularly at risk. Western Scotland emerges as a stronghold for peatlands.

articles.title: Has the World Lost Its Collective Mind?
articles.author: Edwin
articles.summary: There was a lot of hype about global warming in the press. Now we have the coldest winter in more than 50 years. The objective was to shut down small local businesses and end commuting, so we have an office space crisis that will hit the economy. This was all part of the climate change agenda. The Greens now want bloodshed to save the planet from climate change.

articles.title: York Library hosts 2025 series on climate change: From sea level rise to offshore wind
articles.author: Special to Seacoastonline
articles.summary: The York Public Library is hosting its fourth annual educational series focusing on climate change titled 'Climate Change: Coastal Impacts and Resources'. The series will run from February through April. Most of the programs will be held online via Zoom, with some in-person sessions at the Library's Community Room or off-site locations.

articles.title: As sea levels rise around Eastport peninsula, resilience authority seeks ways to mitigate damage
articles.author: James Matheson
articles.summary: The Resilience Authority of Annapolis and Anne Arundel County is a joint venture between the city and county to deal with rising sea levels, flooding and erosion in the watersheds around the Eastport peninsula. The initiative received a $969,000 grant from the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation through the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The next step is selecting locations and presenting plans for mitigation measures.

articles.title: Groynes removed from Hunstanton beach after storm Darragh
articles.author: Gabriella Crisp
articles.summary: Coastal work is being carried out at Hunstanton beach until January 31. It comes after Storm Darrah caused four groynes to partially collapse. The changes in the coastal processes mean the groynes are now ineffective. The work will not restrict access to the other areas of the beach.

articles.title: Unsafe groynes removed from beach after storm
articles.author: Gabriella Crisp
articles.summary: Coastal work is being carried out at Hunstanton beach until January 31. It comes after Storm Darrah caused four groynes to partially collapse. The changes in the coastal processes mean the groynes are now ineffective. The work will not restrict access to the other areas of the beach.

articles.title: AI Group Welcomes New Chief Scientist Tony Haymet
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Professor Tony Haymet has been appointed as Australia's new chief scientist. His expertise on energy and climate matters will be especially important as Australia continues to work through a prolonged energy transition. His work measuring the impact of carbon emissions, particularly on ocean temperatures, makes him uniquely qualified to meaningfully contribute to the debate. Professor Haymet can be expected to play a key role in the development of artificial intelligence.

articles.title: SADC hosts 30th Southern Africa Regional Climate Outlook Forum
articles.author: Michel Haoses
articles.summary: The 30th Southern Africa Regional Climate Outlook Forum will be held in Antananarivo, Madagascar from 28 to 30 January. The theme of the forum is 'Closing the early warning gap together in SADC Region' and the theme is inspired by the World Meteorological Organisation's focus for World meteorological Day last year. The forum will focus on collaborative strategies to strengthen climate resilience and mainstreaming climate information into decision making processes across key socioeconomic sectors. It will also take place against the backdrop of the SADc region's call for a regional humanitarian appeal to assist member states affected by drought and floods.

articles.title: Emotions' Role in Coping with Natural Disasters
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Carahatas in Cuba and Yumbo and Salgar in Colombia and Concepción in Chile are threatened by rising sea levels caused by climate change. Gonzalo Lizarralde and his co-researchers spent time in four Latin American communities affected by recent climate disasters. They found that fear, anxiety, anger, pride and reverence for nature are important factors in whether people decide to implement solutions to the extreme weather events they face.

articles.title: LA wildfires: Did climate change make them worse?
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: Two large wildfires that exploded on January 7 in Los Angeles were the most destructive and potentially the costliest in the city's history. The Palisades and Eaton fires have so far caused 28 known fatalities and the destruction of more than 16,000 structures. The hot, dry and windy conditions that drove the LA fires were about 35% more likely due to climate change, according to World Weather Attribution (WWA).

articles.title: New Australian map to enhance conservation of species in ice-free Antarctica
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Australian researchers have created a detailed map of Antarctica's ice-free land that they say will help protect the continent's biodiversity. The team unveiled the new high-resolution map and a hierarchical classification system of the ecosystems in Antarctica on Wednesday. Antarctica's ecosystems contain the vast majority of its biodiversity and are under threat from human activity and climate change.

articles.title: Scientists blame climate change for the Los Angeles wildfires: Hot, dry and windy conditions that drove the fires were 35% more likely due to global warming
articles.author: SHIVALI BEST
articles.summary: The World Weather Attribution, a network of researchers from the US, UK and Europe, says climate change is to blame for the devastating Los Angeles wildfires that killed 28 people and destroyed more than 10,000 homes. They warn the fire-risk conditions could become another 35% more likely if global temperatures rise 2.6°C above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: What impact did the jet stream have on winter storms in Georgia? See what experts said.
articles.author: Erica Van Buren
articles.summary: The recent snow storms left Augusta and surrounding area with frigid temperatures and piles of snow. Some scientists argue that climate change is affecting the jet stream. The polar jet stream and the polar vortex are two rings of fast-moving air around the Arctic. Global warming is changing these rings in ways that allow freezing air from the Arctic to intrude on the warmer mid-latitude regions.

articles.title: Ocean surface warming rises 4x over 4 decades
articles.summary: The rate of ocean warming has more than quadrupled over the past four decades. In 2023 and early 2024, global ocean temperatures hit record highs for straight 450 days. The team found that the sea surface warming went up faster in the past 10 years than in earlier decades.

articles.title: Canada Boosts Climate Adaptation for Safer Communities 29 January
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The impacts of climate change are becoming more severe and more frequent in Canada. Natural Resources Canada announced $2.7 million in funding for five projects based in northern Ontario under the Climate Change Adaptation Program (CCAP). The projects aim to support professionals, decision makers and First Nation communities to advance climate change adaptation plans and actions.

articles.title: ActionAid launches project to build community-resilience against climate change
articles.author: GTonline
articles.summary: Actionaid Ghana (AAG) launched a project to build resilience of rural communities in the Upper West and Savannah Regions. The €1m project christened: 'Strengthening Community Resilience through Community Action Plans' aimed to execute 140 sub-projects in 110 communi­ties in nine selected districts in the two regions. It sought to improve access to water resources and irrigation infrastructure, and enhance affor­estation and soil health in targeted communities. The eleven-month project was funded by the German Agency for International Cooperation (GIZ) under the European Union Ghana Agricultural Programme's (EU­GAP's) Resilient Against Climate Change project.

articles.title: Climate change fueled intensity of California wildfires: Study
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change increased the likelihood and intensity of the hot, dry and windy conditions that fanned the flames of the recent devastating Southern California wildfires. Global warming boosted the likelihood of high fire weather conditions in this month's fires by 35% and its intensity by 6%. Once-in-a-decade super strong Santa Ana winds, a dry autumn that followed two wet years, hot weather, dry air and vulnerable houses in fire-prone areas were factors in the fast-moving fires.

articles.title: Climate Change: A Tale of Two Theories
articles.author: Stephen Andrews
articles.summary: This article challenges the "settled science" narrative that climate change is driven by man-made carbon emissions. It suggests that the current rise in global temperature may be explained by a combination of two alternative theories: Cosmic Ray Hypothesis and Winter Gatekeeper hypothesis. The correlation between solar cycles and temperature suggests that global warming is caused directly or indirectly by the sun.

articles.title: Climate change made LA fires worse, scientists say
articles.author: Matt McGrath
articles.summary: Climate change was a major factor behind the hot, dry weather that gave rise to the devastating LA fires. It made those weather conditions about 35% more likely, according to World Weather Attribution. 30 people have died and more than 10,000 homes have been destroyed in the fast-spreading, destructive fires that broke out in early January.

articles.title: Study: Climate change worsened fires
articles.author: news@pressenterprise.net
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change increased the likelihood and intensity of the hot, dry and windy conditions that fanned the flames of the recent fires, according to the IPCC.   ...  .   in the IPCC's report on climate change.

articles.title: 'Doomsday Clock' nears midnight
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists has advanced its famous "Doomsday Clock" to 89 seconds till midnight, the closest it has ever been to the end of the world. It cites threats such as climate change, proliferation of nuclear weapons, instability in the Middle East, pandemics and artificial intelligence in military operations.

articles.title: 'Doomsday Clock' moves closer to midnight
articles.summary: The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists has advanced its famous "Doomsday Clock" to 89 seconds till midnight, the closest it has ever been. The group cites threats such as climate change, proliferation of nuclear weapons, instability in the Middle East, pandemics and incorporation of artificial intelligence in military operations.

articles.title: Africa: Climate Finance and Care Services - Why Public Investment Is Necessary
articles.author: Caren Grown
articles.summary: The care economy is an important but unrecognised sector for climate change adaptation. In countries around the world, deficits in paid care services are widespread. Many countries have allocated public resources for care services, alleviating some of the unpaid care workload borne largely by women. Estimates of the costs of adaptation to climate change in developing countries range from US$215 billion to US$387 billion per year up to 2030. Only 4% of estimated total climate finance committed by donors has been targeted for health.

articles.title: Fall River Faces Lowest Risk in Massachusetts From Climate Change
articles.author: Barry Richard
articles.summary: Massachusetts Office of Energy and Environmental Affairs has posted its report "Adapting to Climate Change" on its website. Fall River has the lowest risk from climate change in the state. Stacker ranked the most expensive climate disasters by the billions since 1980 by the total cost of all damages.

articles.title: Helen Morgan brings MPs together to demand action over flood risk
articles.author: Shropshire Live
articles.summary: Helen Morgan, the MP for North Shropshire, brought together a cross-party group of MPs to question DEFRA and the Met Office about flooding preparation after severe storms. Helen convened the discussion in response to the significant impacts of Storm Darragh and the ongoing challenges posed by Storm Herminia.

articles.title: Global warming climate training for Brent schoolteachers
articles.author: Mike Brooke
articles.summary: Teachers from 14 Brent schools have so far completed 'carbon literacy' training. The course aims to improve teachers' understanding of how to discuss environmental issues with children and parents. Primary schools like Fryent and Gladstone Park as well as Anson Primary School teach climate subjects. 20 Brent schools signed up to a 'whole school' approach to give some TLC to the planet.

articles.title: Teaching the teachers to teach climate change
articles.author: Mike Brooke
articles.summary: Teachers from 14 Brent schools have so far completed 'carbon literacy' training. The course aims to improve teachers' understanding of how to discuss environmental issues with children and parents. Primary schools like Fryent and Gladstone Park teach climate subjects to 'plant the seeds of change' in the next generation. 20 Brent schools signed up to a 'whole school' approach to give some TLC to the planet.

articles.title: Study: Climate change fed fires
articles.summary: Global warming boosted the likelihood of high fire weather conditions in this month's fires by 35% and its intensity by 6%. Once-in-a-decade Santa Ana winds, a dry autumn, hot weather, dry air and vulnerable houses in fire-prone areas were factors in the fast-moving fires that destroyed thousands of homes and killed at least 29 people in Southern California.

articles.title: The Ocean Surface Is Warming Over 400% Faster Than in The 1980s
articles.author: Tessa Koumoundouros
articles.summary: The tops of the oceans are warming more than four times faster than in the late 1980s. Sea surface temperatures were the highest on record for the month of December across the northern half of the Atlantic Ocean. If the current trend continues, in the next 20 years we will exceed the sea surface temperature rise we've experienced in the last 40 years.

articles.title: Ocean heatwave likely killed 30,000 fish off Western Australia coast, government says
articles.author: Donna Lu Science writer
articles.summary: 30,000 fish washed up on beaches near Gnoorea Point, 50km south-west of Karratha, Western Australia's Pilbara coast. The nearshore waters along the Pilbara Coast are about 31C, which is 2-3C above normal for this time of year. There is a marine heatwave warning for WA's north coast and Gascoyne bioregions. There are concerns that the overheated water will cause damage to Ningaloo reef, Exmouth Gulf and Shark Bay in the Gascoysne.

articles.title: Study says climate change made conditions that fed California wildfires more likely, more intense
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change increased the likelihood and intensity of the recent Southern California wildfires, according to a scientific study. Once-in-a-decade Santa Ana winds, a dry autumn, hot weather, dry air and vulnerable houses in fire-prone areas were factors in the fast-moving fires that destroyed thousands of homes.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: melting permafrost threatens landscapes and lives in Arctic regions
articles.author: Paul Brown
articles.summary: In the early days of the global warming debate there was a lot of optimism from the oil lobby about the upsides of the temperature increase for northern climes. Some scientists, particularly Russian advisors to the Kremlin, saw a strategic advantage in climate change. They calculated that a warmer climate would improve conditions for growing key food crops further north, particularly wheat. Droughts in the US would cut food production there, further altering the balance of power in Russia's favour. What the Russians didn't foresee was the melting of the permafrost, which is currently threatening up to 3 million people in Arctic regions.

articles.title: Gun numbers grow in decades since Port Arthur massacre
articles.author: Farid Farid
articles.summary: Australia's number of registered firearms is 25 per cent higher since the Port Arthur massacre in 1996, according to a report released today. The number of firearms registered in Australia has increased since then by 25 percent since the massacre at Port Arthur in 1996.

articles.title: UN confirms US withdrawal from Paris Climate accord
articles.author: Sharjah24
articles.summary: On his first day back in office, Trump announced that the US would pull out of the Paris Agreement. The US contributes 22% to the UNFCCC budget, projected at $96.5 million for 2024-2025. Michael Bloomberg's foundation will cover the funding gap. Argentina is reconsidering its participation in the accord.

articles.title: Cyclone threat looms for rain-battered region
articles.author: Fraser Barton
articles.summary: The ocean temperature of the Coral Sea is about 28 to 30 degrees. It's ideal conditions for further development in the sea. The development of the sea will be the real watch point, according to the Bureau of Meteorology's Jonathan How. It will depend on how long the development lasts.

articles.title: ‘A perfect storm': How climate change made the LA wildfires more likely
articles.author: Rebecca Ann Hughes
articles.summary: A new study has found that the LA wildfire season is becoming longer and more dangerous. The study was carried out by 32 researchers, including leading wildfire scientists from the US and Europe. The scientists warn that LA will get drier and more flammable with continued fossil fuel, and it will be more likely to get hot, dry and dangerous.

articles.title: Doomsday Clock nears midnight amid global threats
articles.summary: The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists has advanced its famous 'Doomsday Clock' to 89 seconds till midnight, the closest it has ever been. The clock had stood at 90 seconds to midnight for the past two years. The group cites threats that include climate change, proliferation of nuclear weapons, instability in the Middle East, pandemics and incorporation of artificial intelligence in military operations.

articles.title: Climate finance and care services: why public investment is necessary
articles.author: Caren Grown
articles.summary: The care economy is an important but unrecognised sector for climate change adaptation. In countries around the world, deficits in paid care services are widespread, especially in urban areas where informal settlements, poor access to energy, fuel, clean water and basic services make caregiving especially difficult. Estimates of the costs of adaptation to climate change in developing countries range from US$215 billion to US$387 billion per year up to 2030. Only 4% of estimated total adaptation finance committed by donors has been targeted for health and 2% for education.

articles.title: Doomsday Clock Moved Forward by 1 Second, Now at 89 Seconds to Midnight
articles.author: Syeda Qandeel Zehra
articles.summary: The Doomsday Clock has been moved forward by one second. It is now set at 89 seconds to midnight. The previous record was set in 2023 when the clock was moved to 90 seconds before midnight. There are nuclear threats, climate change, and geopolitical tensions. Global leaders must take decisive actions to address nuclear disarmament and climate change.

articles.title: Climate Future Film Festival is Friday
articles.summary: The Lake Placid Center for the Arts is hosting a Climate Future Film Festival on Friday, Jan. 31. Bill McKibben is the honorary judge of the festival. He is also the founder of Third Act, a national movement of Americans over the age of 60 working together to safeguard our climate and protect future generations of life on earth. Third Act's Upstate New York chapter is holding a meet and greet in the lobby at 6:30 p.m. prior to the screening.

articles.title: Economic losses from natural  disasters eased globally but soared in US
articles.summary: Economic losses from natural disasters in the United States in 2024 were above average, reflecting another year of costly severe storms, floods and droughts. Hurricanes Helene and Milton caused US$217.8 billion in economic losses in the US last year. Global insured losses, meanwhile, climbed 15.1% to US$145 billion.

articles.title: Somalia: UNDP Somalia Trains Journalists in Mogadishu On Climate Change Reporting and Awareness
articles.summary: The UNDP hosted a training session for 15 Somali journalists in Mogadishu today. The session aimed to enhance the journalists' understanding of climate change issues and equip them with the necessary skills to report on the topic effectively. The training focused on Somalia's pressing climate challenges, including recurring droughts, floods, and the impact on livelihoods and food security. Journalists were introduced to key climate change concepts and the importance of accurate reporting.

articles.title: Study finds ocean-surface warming four times faster now than late-1980s
articles.author: C to I News Desk
articles.summary: Study shows ocean-surface warming four times faster now than late-1980s. Global ocean temperatures hit record highs for 450 days straight in 2023 and early 2024. Some of this warmth came from El Niño, a natural warming event in the Pacific. The rest of the record warmth is explained by the sea surface warming up faster in the past 10 years.

articles.title: A marine heatwave in north-west Australia is killing huge numbers of fish. It's heading south
articles.author: Matt Rayson
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of fish have died off north-western Australia due to a long-lasting marine heatwave. It's the second-worst in Western Australia's recorded history. The 2010-11 heatwave devastated seas off the WA coast and killed 7,000 humpback whales. This current heatwave has concentrated on the northern coastline but may spread south in coming weeks.

articles.title: Marine Heatwave Hits NW Australia, Fish Deaths Rise
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of fish have died off northwestern Australia as a long-lasting marine heatwave intensifies. The 2010-11 heatwave in Western Australia devastated fisheries and ecosystems further down the WA coast. This current heatwave has concentrated on the northern coastline, but may spread south in coming weeks.

articles.title: UK eyes third Heathrow runway in growth takeoff bid
articles.author: Ben Perry
articles.summary: Greenpeace warned expanding Heathrow would increase "noise, air pollution and climate emissions" Adrian DENNIS.  Originally published on docafp.com, part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange, which is a BLOX digital content exchange.

articles.title: New study shows ocean-surface warming four times faster now than late-1980s
articles.author: India Blooms News Service
articles.summary: Ocean temperatures are increasing at 0.27 degrees Celsius per decade. Global ocean temperatures hit record highs for 450 days straight in 2023 and early 2024. The Earth's energy imbalance has roughly doubled since 2010, in part due to increasing greenhouse gas concentrations and because the Earth is reflecting less sunlight to space than before.

articles.title: Experts call for united action on draft climate change law in Africa
articles.author: Tribune
articles.summary: Experts call for united action on draft climate change law in Africa. Law seeks to promote sustainable development by upholding the principles of the UNFCCC. It also aims to tackle the impact of climate change on the continent.      .

articles.title: Climate change worsened likelihood of California wildfires: Report
articles.author: The Hill
articles.summary: The recent wildfires in California were worsened by climate change, according to the World Weather Attribution. Human-induced climate change is increasing wildfires in many regions of the world, as hot, dry and windy weather conditions increase the risk of fires both starting and spreading.

articles.title: Australian weather forecast: Jane Bunn looks at rain set to drench Queensland while Melbourne and Adelaide swelter
articles.author: Jane Bunn
articles.summary: Rain is likely to affect areas from Mackay through to Cairns in a weather pattern that brings rain day after day. Extreme heat is set to return to southeastern Australia. Most parts of southeastern Australia will be near 40C for several days in a row. The last spike of heat lasted for just one day.

articles.title: 'Heartbreaking' losses prompt storm precautions for tropical NQ growers
articles.author: Steph Allen
articles.summary: Banana and sugar cane growers in the far north are preparing for the storm season. Up to 300mm of rain is expected heading into the weekend. Leon Collins is a banana and cane farmer in Tully, north of Sydney. He is bunking down.

articles.title: ​Global sea levels may rise by up to 1.9m by 2100, exceeding projections: NTU study​
articles.summary: According to Singapore's third national climate change study published in 2024, mean sea levels could rise by 23cm in the best possible scenario, or by 1.15m in the worst-case scenario, by the end of the century. NTU's new study showed that under such a scenario, the projected sea-level rise is between 0.5m and 1.9m instead of 0.6m as previously estimated.

articles.title: A dire prediction from 2008
articles.author: Robin Westenra
articles.summary: Forum for the Future presented a radical set of 'possible futures' to stir debate about how to avert the worst effects of global warming. The study envisages a shift to a service based economy, people no longer owning cars and using bicycles, and the eastern seaboard of the U.S. being protected by an eco-concrete wall.

articles.title: Climate change made LA wildfires worse, says study
articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.summary: Global warming caused by burning fossil fuels made Los Angeles wildfires 35 percent more likely, according to a study. The study does not address the direct causes of the deadly wildfires that erupted around Los Angeles on January 7, killing at least 29 people and destroying more than 10,000 homes.

articles.title: Huge chunks of Australia's biggest cities wouldn't exist without Chinese cash
articles.author: Shannon Molloy
articles.summary: Voters back Peter Dutton's proposal to restrict foreign investment in real estate if the Coalition wins the election. Experts warn it will have a minimal impact on the country's housing crisis. They point to the fact that Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane wouldn't exist if not for foreign investors.

articles.title: Councillor claims upcoming session on climate change could 'brainwash' kids
articles.summary: Moyne Shire Council will deliver an interactive in-school climate change workshop at Hawkesdale on February 19. The session is to be led by youth climate changemaker Kal Glanznig and mental health advocate Cooper Chapman. It is designed to "equip students with practical strategies to manage eco-anxiety, understand climate change and take meaningful action".

articles.title: Climate change worsened likelihood of California wildfires: Report
articles.author: Lauren Irwin
articles.summary: The recent wildfires in California were worsened by climate change, according to a new report. The study was released Tuesday by the World Weather Attribution. It found that human-caused climate change increased the chances of hot, dry and windy conditions in the area, which caused the fires to worsen. The dry season has also gotten longer and Santa Ana winds could fuel the spread of wildfires.

articles.title: Climate Change Made Ferocious Los Angeles Wildfires More Likely: Study
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: Human-driven climate change set the stage for the devastating Los Angeles wildfires by reducing rainfall, parching vegetation, and extending the overlap between drought conditions and flammable drought conditions, according to climate scientists.   .   "Climate change" is to blame for the wildfires in Los Angeles.

articles.title: Climate change made ferocious LA wildfires more likely
articles.author: The Philadelphia Inquirer
articles.summary: Human-driven climate change set the stage for the devastating Los Angeles wildfires by reducing rainfall, parching vegetation, and extending the overlap between flammable drought conditions and powerful Santa Ana, according to the report.   .   "Climate change increased the risk of the devastating LA wildfires"

articles.title: Research Links Climate Change to Intense Pakistan Rainfall
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change likely increased the intense rainfall that flooded large parts of Pakistan, according to a study by the World Weather Attribution group. Around 33 million people are affected by the rains, floods and impacts such as landslides, killing at least 1,100 people and destroying infrastructure, homes, agricultural land and livestock. Pakistan Meteorological Department said that it was the wettest August since records began in 1961.

articles.title: Climate Report: Africa Faces Water Stress, Hazards
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Water stress and hazards like withering droughts and devastating floods are hitting African communities, economies and ecosystems hard. Rainfall patterns are disrupted, glaciers are disappearing and key lakes are shrinking. High water stress is estimated to affect 250 million people in Africa and is expected to displace up to 700 million people by 2030. Four out of five African countries are unlikely to have sustainably managed water resources by 2030, according to the State of the Climate in Africa 2021 report. Africa's climate has warmed more than the global average since 1950.

articles.title: Get ready: Editorial on the wide-ranging impacts of climate change
articles.author: The Editorial Board
articles.summary: In 2024, one in seven children around the world had to miss school for prolonged periods due to climate change-induced extreme weather events. About 54.7 million of these children were from India. Flooding des­troyed hundreds of schools in Pakistan and Afghanistan. There is a link between worsening weather and child marriages. Climate change can also significantly impact language.

articles.title: Ocean-Surface Warming Four Times Faster Now Than Late-1980s
articles.author: Eurasia Review
articles.summary: The rate of ocean warming has more than quadrupled over the past four decades. Global ocean temperatures hit record highs for 450 days straight in 2023 and early 2024. The Earth's energy imbalance has roughly doubled since 2010 due to increasing greenhouse gas concentrations and because the Earth is reflecting less sunlight to space than before.

articles.title: Climate change fuels forced migrations, says survey
articles.author: Joseph Prosper
articles.summary: Extreme weather events have been highlighted as one of the leading global risks in WEF's Global Risks Perception Survey (GRPS) 2025. Climate change is becoming more evident every year. The effects of climate change are deeply intertwined with many other global risks, including the mass migration of people. Sub-Saharan Africa alone faces an estimated cost of $30 to $50 billion annually over the next decade due to climate change.

articles.title: Climate change made Los Angeles 35% more primed to burn, scientists say
articles.author: Bloomberg
articles.summary: Climate change made Southern California's dangerous wildfire conditions 35% more likely than they would have been before the industrial era, according to a new analysis by the scientific group World Weather Attribution. Greenhouse gas pollution raised temperatures, made drought more likely and extended the duration of fire season, contributing to the most destructive fire disaster in U.S. history.

articles.title: Climate change made conditions that fed California wildfires more likely, intense: Study
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: Global warming increased the likelihood and intensity of the recent Southern California wildfires by 35% and its intensity by 6%. Once-in-a-decade super strong Santa Ana winds, a dry autumn, hot weather, dry air and vulnerable houses in fire-prone areas were factors in the fast-moving fires that destroyed thousands of homes and killed at least 29 people.

articles.title: Farmers feeling the impact of last week's freeze
articles.summary: The snow has melted and farmers are dealing with the aftermath of the freezing temperatures now that the snow has been melted.    -     -  .  Â   in this article.  - "The Farmer's Report" is broken into sections.

articles.title: CO2 Rise Threatens Global Ocean Current Stability
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Camille Hankel is a postdoctoral researcher in the Cooperative Institute for Climate, Ocean and Ecosystem Studies. She studies how the rate of rising CO2 affects the climate system. She found that when carbon dioxide levels rise more gradually, they have less impact on the ocean circulation. The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, which includes the Gulf Stream ocean current, is important for Earth's climate. It transports heat from the South Atlantic to the higher latitudes closer to the North Pole.

articles.title: Climate change made deadly Los Angeles wildfires more likely: Study
articles.author: Halis Sunnetci
articles.summary: Climate change increased the likelihood of the devastating Los Angeles wildfires by 35%, according to a study by World Weather Attribution. The fires broke out on Jan. 7, killing 29 people and destroying more than 16,000 homes. The economic loss from the disaster is estimated to exceed $250 billion.

articles.title: Climate change increased the odds of Los Angeles' devastating fires, researchers say
articles.author: Engadget
articles.summary: Easton and Palisades fires killed many people and destroyed many homes in Los Angeles. Scientists believe climate change is to blame for the extreme weather events this January, which have been caused by the fires.       - World.com.

articles.title: Climate change intensified LA fires: Analysis by 32 climate scientists
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Climate change worsened the Los Angeles wildfires and made it 35% more likely than they would have been in conditions without human-caused warming, according to a new analysis by 32 climate scientists. The hot, dry, and windy conditions that drove the fires were due to warming caused primarily by the burning of oil, gas, and coal.

articles.title: Joe Rogan's blistering take on claims climate change caused wildfires
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Joe Rogan claims that climate change is not the reason why Los Angeles has been suffering from devastating wildfires. The LA fires, which began on January 7, have killed at least 28 people and destroyed over 10,000 homes so far, while also destroying over 1,000 structures.

articles.title: The pioneering science linking climate to weather disasters
articles.author: Iosco County News Herald
articles.summary: Extreme weather is becoming more destructive as the world warms, but how can we say that climate change intensified the fires in Los Angeles, typhoons in the Philippines, or flooding in Spain due to climate change? It's not possible to say. It's a matter of opinion.

articles.title: Climate change made conditions that fed California wildfires more likely, more intense: Study
articles.author: Canoe
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change increased the likelihood and intensity of the recent Southern California wildfires, according to a scientific study. The number (35%) doesn't sound like much, but it's a significant increase, the study found.   .

articles.title: Ocean heatwave likely killed 30,000 fish off Western Australia coast, government says
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: There was a mass fish kill along Western Australia's Pilbara coast. An estimated 30,000 fish washed up earlier in January at beaches near Gnoorea Point, 50 km south-west of Karratha. It is likely that prolonged thermal stress due to the conditions is associated with the deaths.

articles.title: Discovering ancient microorganisms inside Swiss glaciers
articles.author: Swissinfo
articles.summary: Melting glaciers release unknown bacteria and viruses into the environment. These microorganisms could help to tackle some major global problems, from plastic pollution to antibiotic resistance, according to the scientists.   .   "Melting Glaciers caused by global warming release largely unknown bacteria, viruses and other microorganisms.

articles.title: Sea turtles make a comeback as conservation efforts pay off
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Turtle populations continue to face unpredictable challenges from climate change, according to the study.      Â  .  ...   in the study by the University of California, San Francisco, and the International Agency for Research on Climate Change.

articles.title: Climate change made LA wildfires worse, says study
articles.author: France24
articles.summary: Climate change was a major factor behind the hot, dry weather that led to ferocious wildfires in LA in January. Global warming made the blazes 35 percent more likely, according to the study. The study was published in the journal "The Journal of Climatology".

articles.title: 'World's biggest iceberg' drifts towards Antarctic penguin island
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The 'world's biggest iceberg', A23a, is drifting toward South Georgia Island. It is more than twice the size of London. Scientists are concerned it could disrupt the feeding patterns of young penguins and seals. The iceberg is slowly moving from Antarctica.

articles.title: As sea levels rise around Eastport peninsula, resilience authority seeks ways to mitigate damage
articles.author: Baltimore Sun
articles.summary: The Resilience Authority of Annapolis and Anne Arundel County is rolling out an effort to deal with rising sea levels. It wants to know where members of the public are experiencing climate change in the area. It looks to be heavy on community engagement.

articles.title: New study decodes when the Nicobarese people came to the island
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: Austroasiatic ancestors of the Nicobarese migrated to the island more than 11,000 years ago, according to the new study.       -  Â   y   e   Y   i
