articles.title: Climate change set the table for Los Angeles wildfires
articles.author: Ars Technica
articles.summary: Global warming caused mainly by burning of fossil fuels made the recent deadly fires around Los Angeles about 35 times more likely to occur. Today's climate is heated 2.3°C, according to a rapid attribution analysis released Tuesday by scientists.  "Climate change is continuing to destroy lives and livelihoods in the US"

articles.title: Orcas hunt great white sharks in Australian waters and eat their livers, 50cm bite mark confirms
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Behaviour of'remarkable predators' also seen off coast of South Africa could affect ecosystem, researchers say. Follow our Australia news live blog for the latest updates. Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast for the news you need.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: melting permafrost threatens landscapes and lives in Arctic regions
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: In the early days of the global warming debate there was a lot of optimism from the oil lobby about the upsides of the temperature increase for northern climes. One example was that warmer weather would create conditions for a flourishing wine industry in England. Some scientists, particularly scientists, are sceptical about this.

articles.title: Climate change could spark outbreaks of DIARRHOEA in Britain, scientists warn
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Climate change is already wreaking havoc on Britain's weather. Scientists from the University of Surrey say that climate change could spark outbreaks of natural disasters.      .  ,   in the future, according to the scientists.  In the present day, humans could be next in the firing line.

articles.title: Climate change made conditions that fed California wildfires more likely, more intense
articles.author: Naharnet
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change increased the likelihood and intensity of the recent Southern California wildfires, according to a scientific study. However, the level of global warming's (35%) doesn't sound like much, because there are many other causes that go into the still smoldering fires.

articles.title: Climate change made deadly Los Angeles wildfires more likely: Study
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Climate change increased the likelihood of the devastating Los Angeles wildfires by 35%, according to a study by World Weather Attribution (WWA). A 1.3-degree Celsius rise in global temperatures since the pre-industrial era extended dry periods, making vegetation more flammable.

articles.title: Climate group publishes guide on how municipalities can put a dollar value on nature
articles.author: Moosejaw Today
articles.summary: The Intact Centre on Climate Adaptation published a guide on Wednesday. It encourages municipalities to assign specific dollar values to natural assets, such as wetlands and coastal dunes, as well as to their financial reporting. The guide is published by the University of Waterloo.

articles.title: Trump voters not the climate enemies you think they are
articles.author: Asiatimes
articles.summary: Carteret County, North Carolina's coastal towns and villages are being swallowed by the rising Atlantic. Its voters returned Donald Trump to the White House, a man who denies the science of climate change and had withdrawn his country from the UN. He also withdraws the US from the Paris Climate Agreement.

articles.title: AI, wars and climate change mean it's later than ever on the 'Doomsday Clock'
articles.author: NBC News
articles.summary: Earth is moving closer to destruction, a science-oriented advocacy group said. It advanced its famous 'Doomsday Clock' to the closest ever to midnight, as it advanced the Doomsday Clock to the famous Doomsday Clock's current position of 2.5 seconds.

articles.title: Climate change made Los Angeles 35% more primed to burn, scientists say
articles.author: Japan Times
articles.summary: Greenhouse gas pollution raised temperatures, made drought more likely and extended the duration of fire season, according to the UNFCCC. It also raised temperatures and increased duration of the fire season. It increased the risk of droughts and increased the temperature of the fires.

articles.title: Los Angeles wildfires linked to climate change, report states
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: The devastating wildfires in Los Angeles have killed at least 29 people. A study by 32 scientists, including wildfire scientists from the U.S. and Europe, says human-caused climate change is to blame for the fires. The study is part of the World Weather Attribution project.

articles.title: As the Black Summer megafires neared, people rallied to save wildlife and domestic animals. But ...
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: As the 2019–2020 megafires took hold across eastern Australia, many of us reeled at the prospect of such a thing happening in the future. It's not a good thing.    It's very dangerous. It could be very destructive.

articles.title: Here's how climate change fueled the Los Angeles fires
articles.author: National Public Radio
articles.summary: Extreme conditions helped fuel the fast-moving fires that destroyed thousands of homes in California. Scientists are working to figure out how climate change played a role in the disaster and are trying to determine the cause of the fires.      Â

articles.title: Has the World Lost Its Collective Mind?
articles.author: Armstrong Economics
articles.summary: There are outrageous forecasts about global warming and how the entire earth will be destroyed. The press loved to push this nonsense out so the government would panic and raise taxes, and shift money to fake analysis to pretend they are doing what they say they are not.

articles.title: International conference on water security, climate change begins at UET
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: ICWSCC 2025 was inaugurated at the University of Engineering and Technology (UET) Lahore on Wednesday. The event was hosted by Center of Excellence in Water Resource (CEWR) and is a two-day International Conference on Water Security and Climate Change.

articles.title: Smart carbon dioxide removal yields economic and environmental benefits
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Last year, Earth exceeded 1.5 degrees Celsius of warming above preindustrial times. The threshold is the threshold beyond which wildfires, droughts, floods and other climate impacts are expected to escalate in the coming years. The world is already experiencing more heat.

articles.title: A green vision for Pakistan's survival
articles.author: Soha Nisar
articles.summary: Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement sends shockwaves through international climate efforts. For Pakistan, the Paris Agreement symbolised more than a global pact; it was a lifeline. Pakistan bears a disproportionate share of climate impacts, from glacial melts threatening water security to catastrophic floods submerging entire regions. Pakistan's sprawling rural areas and growing urban populations represent vast opportunities to pioneer sustainable solutions. Investments in energy efficiency, smart grids, and green infrastructure can transform Pakistan into a model of climate resilience for the Global South. The China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) emerges as a key instrument in this endeavour.

articles.title: From climate anxiety to climate hope
articles.author: Dhirendra Nalbo
articles.summary: July 22, 2024 marked the hottest recorded temperature in human history. 3.6 billion people will experience climate change-related deaths. The World Health Organisation projects 250,000 deaths each year between 2030-2050. Health professionals use the terms climate anxiety and eco-anxiety to elaborate on humanity's psychological response to climate change harms.

articles.title: Study says climate change made conditions that fed wildfires more intense
articles.summary: Global warming increased the likelihood and intensity of the recent devastating Southern California wildfires by 35% and its intensity by 6%. Once-in-a-decade super strong Santa Ana winds, a dry autumn, hot weather, dry air and vulnerable houses in fire-prone areas were factors in the fast-moving fires that destroyed thousands of homes and killed at least 29 people.
